body: THE question sounded laughable: Given that the national median home price recently calculated by the National Association of Realtors is $220,000, is it possible to buy something for that price in New York City? Or even, just to provide some wiggle room, up to $250,000? The initial reactions of real estate brokers in all five boroughs included:
title: What You Can Get for $220,000

body: Officers who pulled over a van for running a stop sign in Marine Park on Wednesday night found more than 500 pounds of marijuana inside, the police said. The van's two occupants ran, but officers caught and arrested one of them, Marcus King, 30, of Miami, the police said. The police said officers also found $25,000 in cash in the van. Mr. King was
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Seize Drugs After A Traffic Stop

body: FROM the ground, the edifice does not seem very imposing: it is a mere bundle of twigs and grass crammed on one of the light poles lining Brooklyn College's athletic field. But the shelter is a sturdy home to an extended family of small green parrots known as Myiopsitta monachus -- monk parakeets to you -- who have thrived in Brooklyn for the
title: In Land Where a Tree Grows, an Immigrant Band Thrives

body: DUSENBERRY--Bernard. 64, died October 6, 2005 after a brief illness. He was a longtime resident of Brooklyn and for 20 years, one of New York's Finest; a highly decorated detective in the NYPD. title: Paid Notice: Deaths DUSENBERRY, BERNARD

body: HERB PREMINGER, a courteous, soft-eyed man who lives on East 17th Street in Midwood, Brooklyn, has managed well during his professional life as a marketing writer. But for nearly three decades, his overwhelming passion has been for his work as an amateur historian of the vanished New York candy store. In his living room one day recently, Mr.
title: THE VOICE; His Madeleine, the Cherry Lime Rickey

body: To the Editor: Jill Eisenstadt, in her article about Jacob Riis Park (''By the Sea, a Moorish Palace Reborn,'' Aug. 14), states that people visited ''despite the lack of public transportation (then as now).'' title: Summer Days In Jacob Riis Park

author: Dorothy Spears is a critic for ArtNews and Art & Antiques magazine.
body: WHEN my doorbell rings, the two brothers chime in unison, ''Your slipcovers!'' Hirschel, 77, wears a Russian fur hat, and says loudly, in brief bursts, like Grandpa from ''The Munsters,'' ''Your slipcovers are ready!'' Archie, 82, carries the slipcovers over his arm. ''We don't make a mess this time,'' he solemnly promises. In the family room, the
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Their Own Little Ottoman Empire

body: FOR years, Maria N. Rodriquez has been hoping her parents would sell their home in East New York, Brooklyn, and move someplace safer and more appealing. Ms. Rodriguez, a 33-year-old mortgage consultant, remembers her anxious teenage years walking down desolate streets in a neighborhood that was one of the most run-down and crime-plagued communities
title: The Boom Spreads: This House Is Valued at

body: It may not replace the Empire State Building or the MetroCard, but the most fitting symbol of New York City today could be the knotty plywood wall enclosing a housing construction site. From Bensonhurst to Morrisania to Flushing, new homes are going up faster now than they have in more than 30 years. In 2004, the city approved the construction of
title: Housing Boom Echoes in All Corners of the City

body: LIKE most of us, Joe Burke worked on Monday. He drove his five-year-old Honda out of Brooklyn and over the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to Staten Island, where he is employed as a baseball catcher. He earns $1,200 a month, plus expenses. Earlier in the day came word that Major League Baseball had suspended one of its multimillion-dollar stars, Rafael
title: About New York; Keeping Unjaded Eye On the Ball

body: To the Editor: ''The Great Awakening,'' by Suketu Mehta (June 19), is a beautiful article about life in Brooklyn. However, though there are those in Park Slope who may know more about gelato in Manhattan than about the roti in Brownsville, as Mr. Mehta stated, many of us not only explore much of Brooklyn, but also regularly enjoy the variety of
title: Savoring Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: I can draw only one conclusion from your special City section about Brooklyn's rebirth: subscription to The Times must be very low in less affluent and distant neighborhoods like East New York, Brownsville, Canarsie, Gravesend, Mill Basin, Marine Park -- just about every neighborhood east of Flatlands Avenue. Shame on you for
title: Not Just Brownstones

author: Suketu Mehta is the author of ''Maximum City: Bombay Lost and Found'' (Knopf).
body: AT a party on the Upper West Side in 2000, a distinguished American author, and longtime Manhattanite, asked where I lived. ''Brooklyn,'' I told him. He snorted. ''Poor people live in Brooklyn.'' Then he turned away to get some meat. Shortly after the party, to see if I could move from my rented apartment in Boerum Hill, I went looking to see what
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/SIGNS OF CHANGING TIMES; The Great Awakening

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: FORTUNATELY or not, lots of prospective home purchases fall through. Daniel MacBride and Georgia Hamilton feel lucky that theirs did. Captivated by the first house they saw, a two-family Victorian in Canarsie, Brooklyn, they immediately offered the asking price of $450,000. title: THE HUNT; A Lot of Chemistry, Even More Patience

body: In the tolling of bells and a tenor's soaring ''Ave Maria,'' in the lowering of flags and the lighting of candles, people around New York were summoned by timeless gestures to mark the passing of the first pope of the digital age. title: Krakow and Beyond: Prayers, Tributes and Awe: New York; Bells for the Pontiff

body: It looked at first like a classic gangland hit. A Mercedes sat abandoned on a Brooklyn highway. A bullet-riddled corpse lay slumped across the seat. The dead man was Edward Lino, a Gambino family captain, who had helped kill Paul Castellano, the boss of bosses, and vault John Gotti into power. It was November 1990 and made men were dying. title: Blood Ties: 2 Officers' Path to Mob Indictments

body: In an unexpected setback to Representative Anthony D. Weiner's mayoral campaign, three Democratic clubs in his southern Brooklyn district have decided to endorse two of his rivals, Gifford Miller and Fernando Ferrer. The Thomas Jefferson Democratic Club and the Highway Democratic Club will support Mr. Miller, the speaker of the City Council, who
title: Democrats Go Beyond Border in Mayor's Race

body: HARVEY--Anna E. On January 11, 2005. Retired research librarian for the New York Times.
